awd_titl_txt: RUI: Assessing the Environmental and Human Drivers and Cultural Dimensions of Changes in Oak Forests of the Eastern U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the changes in abundance of white oak forests in the eastern United States over the past two centuries as well as consider the societal ramifications of these changes.  White oak forests provide numerous material and non-material benefits to society that include commercial timber products, habitat for animal species, and cultural value.  Historically white oaks were an essential component of eastern U.S. forests, being the most abundant tree in forests prior to Euro-American settlement. However, white oak abundance has declined over the past two centuries, motivating this study to understand the reasons for high abundance in the past and the reasons for their decline. The project will investigate two significant processes that likely contributed to white oak abundance in the eighteenth century: vegetation burning by Native Americans to maintain open landscapes, and the occurrence of high-severity droughts that favored drought-tolerant species such as white oak.  The project will analyze present-day forests to understand environmental and historical land-use conditions under which white oak forests persist or decline. To comprehend the human dimensions of oak decline, the project will assess economic and cultural values that stakeholder groups, including Native American communities, ascribe to white oak trees and forests. The research will provide undergraduate student training, including those traditionally underrepresented in the sciences, with field and lab-based educational experiences in STEM fields, specifically in geographic information systems, tree-ring analysis, and statistical modeling. The outcomes of this project will contribute new knowledge for managing oak landscapes to meet economic, ecological, and cultural goals. The framework and methods are scalable to other ecosystems with shared Euro- and Native American land-use legacies. Project findings will be widely shared with entities such as state and federal land management agencies, the Seneca Nation of Indians, and land conservancies. Findings will also be communicated through various means, including a book.

This research will be conducted in the forests of northern New York state and focuses on three central research questions: (1) Were environmental factors or Native American land-use practices responsible for the high abundance of oak and other xeric (dry-site) tree species in the past? (2) Under what environmental and land-use conditions have white oaks regenerated or declined? (3) What material and non-material benefits do white oak trees and forests provide communities in the eastern United States?  Historical records will provide insight into landscape characteristics and land-use practices during late Native American (ca. 1790) and early Euro-American (ca. 1790-1850) settlement period, and will be used to construct a land-use history. Statistical models will determine relationships between past forest composition, environmental conditions (e.g. topography, soils), and Native American land-use.  Dendrochronological studies will be conducted using tree-core samples extracted from remaining old trees to assess patterns of tree growth in relation to drought patterns and land-use changes. Modern tree species composition will be compared with environmental conditions (e.g. soils) and land-use histories to understand settings under which white oak persisted or declined. Surveys and interviews of stakeholders in the study area will be used to ascertain the present-day economic and cultural values associated with white oaks.

por.por_cntn:
Oak forests provide numerous material and non-material benefits that include commercial timber products, habitat for animal species, and cultural and heritage value. Oak was the most abundant tree genus in eastern US forests prior to Euro-American settlement, but its abundance has declined over the last two centuries. The central aim of this project is to better understand this change and its cultural ramifications. Specifically, the project assesses environmental and human drivers of oak forest distribution and change, as well as the cultural impact of oak forest loss in the Genesee Valley region of western New York. Native American land use and landscape heritage are of particular interest in this study. 

To explore these issues, an interdisciplinary team of geographers and their students investigated historical and contemporary forests, employing diverse data sets and methods.

First, oak savanna and low-density oak forest distribution in the Genesee Valley region ca 1795 was modelled and mapped using historic vegetation data to determine how environmental conditions and Native American land use shaped historic oak distribution. By combining predictive spatial modelling with historical analysis of forest accounts, this work confirmed the existence of extensive oak savannas in the study area in the late 18th century. Oak savannas were largely attributable to Onöndowa'ga:' (Seneca) fire use, and secondarily to dry environmental conditions.         

Second, forest conditions were evaluated at 160 field sites in the study area to map and quantify forest compositional change, and to assess the environmental and cultural drivers of such change. Many of these locations were within areas purported to have former oak savannas based on our previous study. Field data collected included tree ring, data, soil samples, forest density, and forest composition. Continued analysis has revealed a suite of interacting factors that are driving a transition from fire-tolerant, xerophytic (dry-adapted) forests often dominated by oak; to fire-intolerant, mesophytic (moisture-loving) forests. Factors are spatially variable and include distance to Native American settlement and deer density.

An analysis of scattered tree loss in the Town of Geneseo, an area dominated by relict oak savanna, was also conducted. Utilizing historical and contemporary air photos, this analysis revealed an 87% loss by area in scattered tree cover between 1938 and 2019. Conversion to cropland, forest conversion and urban development were the leading causes of scattered tree loss during this time period.

Third, evolving interpretations of the “Genesee Oaks” and their cultural meaning were investigated using archival analysis and personal interviews. The Genesee Oaks are a collection of landmark oaks located in the vicinity of Geneseo, New York. These trees occupy former oak savannas identified earlier in our study, and reforested lands. This research focuses on evolving explanations of the origins of these ecologically and culturally important trees, including their probable existence as a land-use legacy of Onöndowa'ga:' (Seneca) fire use. Analysis showed that understanding of the Genesee Oaks has changed over time with knowledge of Native American landscape influence being erased and replaced with colonial narratives falsely attributing the oaks to pioneer Euro-American landscape agency. Growing public interest in the Genesee Oaks and concern for their protection, however, is now reclaiming awareness of Native American history in the Genesee Valley and awareness that the Genesee Oaks represent Onöndowa'ga:' landscape heritage.
